page.title: 01Hudeshope Head
page.content: Part of Middleton Common on the north side of Teesdale. Dissected by Hudeshop Head, a tributary valley with its southward flowing beck. Moorland rises from 300m to 600m and is generally open pasture marked with striahght dry stone walls built for intake (1816) enclosures. A minor road circuits the head to and from Middleton linking three active hill forms engaged in stock rearing. The slopes are littered with lead mining relics - derelict mine buildings, waste heaps, and deep trenches (hushes). The largest hush - Coldberry Gutter - cuts through the watershed of Hardberry Hill. Nearby is Coldberry Moss, still holding water, one of many water tanks formerly used for hushing and ore dressing.
